Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Private Litigation Case Title: Delana L. Ugas v. H&R Block Enterprises Llc et al

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Alameda

Private Litigation Case Title: Lemus v. H&R Block Tax And Business Services, Inc. et al
Weisbarth et al v. H And R Block Financial Advisors Inc et al

Description: H&R Block agreed to settle multistate litigation by providing $1 million to customers who paid for its Peace of Mind guarantee wihtout being told it was optional. It also agreed to pay $2.3 million to the states.

In a settlement with the California Attorney General, H&R Block agreed to pay $4.85 million, including $2.45 million in consumer restitution, to resolve allegations that the tax-preparation company violated state and federal laws in marketing high-cost refund anticipation loans (RALs) mainly to low-income customers.

H&R Block agreed to provide at least $11.4 million in customer refunds and pay $750,000 to New York State to resolve allegations that it steered low- and middle-income customers nationwide to purchase its fee-laden and fraudulently marketed Express IRA product.

An H&R Block subsidiary, Sand Canyon, agreed to pay a setttlement valued at $125 million to resolve allegations it discriminated against African-American and Latino borrowers by offering them loans that had an excessive risk of default.
Tax return preparer H&R Block agreed to pay $4 million to settle allegations of engaging in deceptive trade practices involving more than 61,000 low-income customers.
Agency: New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
Info Source: H&R Block to pay $4 million for deceptive practices, consumer commish says, Associated Press, December 12, 2002 (via Nexis).

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined H&R Block Financial Advisors, Inc., (n/k/a Ameriprise Advisor Services, Inc.) $200,000 for failing to establish adequate supervisory systems and procedures for supervising sales of reverse convertible notes to retail customers.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD censured and fined H&R Block Financial Advisors, Inc., $500,000 for enabling a hedge fund customer in its Orlando, FL branch office to engage in deceptive practices to market time mutual funds. NASD also ordered H&R Block to pay $325,000 to reimburse the affected funds.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
